captions.text:
Hey guys, ChrisFix here and today we are going
to check to see how well seafoam works in

a small engine like this lawnmower, before
I test this out in my car engine, I want to

see if it works in a lawnmower engine. It's
easier to test, it's faster, and we can get

a good idea of what to expect when we do this
test in a car engine. In this test we will

see if seafoam actually does what it says.
we will do this by looking into the engine

before the seafoam, and then seeing how much
carbon buildup is in there. And then we will

run seafoam though the engine, go back in,
and see if the engine cleaner actually remove

the carbon deposits. So lets get some before
footage and see what it looks like before

we add the fuel cleaner. So this is a four
stroke honda engine, for a push mower. Ok,

this is a single piston engine. I have the
piston pushed all the way back so we can get

a good look at this. You can see the little
groves for the two valves, one is an intake

valve, one is an exhaust valve. This is a
carbureted engine. You can see right near

the intake and exhaust valve the engine is
pretty clean but right above that, it is all

dirty, there is some carbon buildup. Lets
see if the seafoam can clean up this carbon
buildup. Before we add
the seafaom, you

want to get the engine 
nice and warm. So
we
are going
to start
it up, and
let

it 
run for a few minutes.

comments.text:
water drip does it too use intravenous drip control
motor with blown head gasket and water gets in that chamber is cleaned.﻿
comments.author: Daryl Morris

comments.text:
I value Seafoam for preserving fuel and eliminating carburator gunk, I've 
been in the lawncare biz for 22 years and carbon buildup was never really a 
problem.﻿
comments.author: Bruno TaTa

comments.text: Try that again using water, and again using transmission fluid.﻿
comments.author: Trojan Horse 86

comments.text:
OK, now take out your spark plug, turn the piston back, now use a jet lance 
and jet off the carbon. Repeat a few times. Tip forward and drain out the 
water, then refit and start.

Zero carbon.﻿
comments.author: mr2gti

comments.text: +mr2gti Thanks for sharing!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
I've only used SeaFoam once.  I had an old straight 6 carbuerated engine in 
a a car that when I started it one day it had a VERY loud tapping or 
banging noise coming from the engine.  I shut the car off right away since 
I was afraid to keep running it like that.  The car had run fine up to that 
point with no engine noise what so ever. This just came out of nowhere.  I 
was young, right out of high school and didn't know much about cars.  I 
thought maybe I had a busted connecting rod or something.    I called down 
to the local car repair place and asked them what they thought it might be. 
 Since it just happened all of the sudden on start up and hadn't made any 
noise previous to this, the guy said it "could' be carbon build up on a 
valve or something.  He said if a piece of carbon gets stuck on a valve it 
can make that really loud tapping/banging noise.  He suggested running a 
full can of SeaFoam through the carbuerator and into the engine.  He said 
have someone rev the engine up as you pour it in little by little.  He said 
it will smoke horribly with a LOT of white smoke coming out the exhaust but 
that's just the SeaFoam burning off.  He said run the whole can through and 
really rev it up and poor it in almost to the point of stalling the engine. 
 I did that and sure enough, after the can of SeaFoam was run through, the 
noise was gone.  The engine was fine ever since then.  I'm definitely a 
believer in SeaFoam after that.﻿
comments.author: Soulrider2012

comments.text:
Yep, I was SO happy it took care of the problem.  Not knowing a lot about 
cars at the time I could easily see that as having turned into a major 
repair bill when actually all the person doing the repair would probably do 
is the same thing I did, SeaFoam.  I made sure to go back and thank the guy 
I talked to who told me about SeaFoam .
comments.author: Soulrider2012

comments.text:
+Soulrider2012 Thanks for sharing! That is pretty good! Cant beat a fix 
like that where it would have costed a lot more to tare down the engine!

comments.author: john jensen

comments.text:
Here's a tip:  Water in a spray bottle will remove carbon too.  Costs 
significantly less.  If you've ever replaced a leaking head gasket on a car 
engine, you've probably seen how clean and polished the leaking cylinder 
looks (assuming you had a leak between a water jacket and a cylinder).  Try 
it.  It's not nearly as fast, but is a lot less poisonous to breathe. 
 Mostly I like the free part.﻿

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Sea foam does work but I've had better results using a spray bottle of 
water, misting it into the intake. My auto shop teacher in high school 
showed me that trick, he said when a drag car (he was old so this was 
probably in the early 1960's) would run-on or ping he and other racers 
would mist water into their carbs to knock out carbon deposits. I've tried 
this on a lot of vehicles and power equipment when I worked at an 
independent shop (cars, trucks, ATVs, Tractors, yard equipment, small town 
shop what we got in we'd fix.) and bore scoped pistons same as you did, it 
works and is basically free, steam is powerful stuff.﻿

Hey Chris, where did you get the orthoscopic camera?  I need to check 
number 4 on my old police car due to a previously leaky intake when I first 
got it.Oh yeah, give marvel mystery oil a try. Its a top cylinder 
lubricant. Use a syringe or other lunger based injection device and cover 
the top of the piston with it. Let it sit for about an hour then start the 
mower back up and check deposits. Just make sure that the piston is flat, 
straight up and down so you get an even dispersal.﻿

comments.text:
i like it in the crank case, my oil used to get dirty after a few hundred 
miles, i ran a whole bottle for a few days, then changed, and changed again 
after a few hundred miles, and switched to motorcraft synthetic blend, and 
subbed in a quart of lucus synthetic stabilizer, now its amber for a few 
k... also i like to do 1/3 1/3 and 1/3rd, crank case, vacuum line, and gas. 
i put it in the gas and oil at the same time, then drive till its low, then 
get it warmed up, and do the vacuum line, then go stand on it on the 
highway, for a few good 2-3 pulls, and i dont run in od during this i want 
it to get hot, if you get on 562 at ridge its like almost a half mile up 
hill, then i get on 75n and turn around at padock, and hit 562 again, and 
its up hill for like a whole mile, then i cruse out the rest of the 
gas(still no od), and go get gas, let her cool down and change tho oil, 
also if you do this with half of the plug gaps closed it will burn out your 
clogged cats, the raw gas raises the egt and melts the cat, ye!(not 
recomended) but i did it in my markvii, and they(the cats) started glowing 
red, and my buddy was like cut it off, i was like nope im going to go stand 
on it if that shit hardens it will clog, and she has run fine for years 
now, but i dont have downstream o2's so my ecu dont know...﻿

I used it today, 1/3 in gas tank, 1/3 in oil, and sprayed throttle body. I 
got a mileage change from 381 to 421 in a full tank on a 2005 hyundai 
elantra gt. Much smoother acceleration too!﻿

Good vid!  I've used this for years, and it does work great.  Instead of 
trickling it in or using a vac line to draw it in, I stick in the sprayer 
from a spray bottle and mist it into the carb.  I especially like to do 
that on motorcycle carbs so I can hit all 4 individually.  When it's time 
to stall it out, I just spray faster - Wally﻿

comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
Impressed you did a borescope inspection. Most just assume that white cloud 
means their engine got cleaned when its mostly the seafoam burning. 
For automobiles a simple water injection system works fine. After failing a 
smog test it was recommended I decarbonize my engine. I borrowed a fiber 
optic borescope and each piston had between 1/8-3/16" hard carbon buildup. 
I was gonna chip it out withb long wire brushes and then vacuum it but was 
advised the carbon would get in the rings and ruin them.Tried seafoam 
techron and pass or dont pay but after use each had little effect by 
viewing the borescope. 
Went to home depot bought some brass needle valves pvc tubing and fittings 
and rigged up a system where I could meter in some distilled water from 
behind the wheel while I drove. Inlet is at the pcv fitting past the 
throttle body. 
Get the engine up to temp and at highway speeds open up a valve creating a 
vacuum leak then plug a hole in the line which sucks the water in. Theres a 
larger diameter tube inline to act as an expansion tube to atomize the 
water. The main tube is just 1/8".
Target ratio is 1:10 water to fuel and after a few gallons of water in a 
few weeks the pistons were all shiny clean and the engine ran smoother and 
revved faster.
Oh and passed smog.
There is more to it than steam cleaning seems H2O when introduced to the 
combustion process separates molecules which directly attack carbon 
breaking it loose and vaporizing it before it passes through the O2 sensors 
and cats so there is no chance of damaging them.
I left the system on and reclean it every few months and once in a while on 
a hot summer day if I am going uphill with the AC on I will crack it open 
to avoid overheating but not sure the effect of that.
You do want to do this only when the motor is hot and never right before 
shut down (so there is no residual moisture leaking down the intake or in 
the oil. Moisture that gets in your oil will see the water vapor burn off 
quickly if its hot)﻿
comments.author: FuckGoogle+

comments.text:
+FuckGoogle+ I will be testing seafoam and water in my truck very very 
soon! Thanks for sharing your trick and experience with the water cleaning!
comments.author: ChrisFix

comments.text:
I have a 2004 SS Impala. I only live no more than a mile from my job. Don't 
really travel too far besides that. I get horrible gas milage because of 
the quick stop & start of my vehicle. I used seafoam this week & I'm 
getting better gas milage but still driving exactly the same. I went from 9 
mpg to 19. I'm very impressed. (I put 1/4 of the can in the gas tank & I 
had 1/4 of gas. Then filled up to a full tank & put another 1/4 of the 
can.) ﻿
